traditional approaches to working with IT it with traditional IT if you ever want to do anything you need to figure
out what kind of resources you need to do it you need to figure out what kind of computing power you need what kind of
memory you might need network connections software all these sorts of things and before you can even get
started on a project you likely have to make some sort of capital expense so you have to spend some money on
infrastructure you then have to order it or somehow get it install it and secure
it all these sorts of things this takes time and it costs money
whereas with the cloud if you have an idea and you want to try something and you know what kind of infrastructure you
need you know perhaps you need a GPU or perhaps you need a server with a lot of memory you can just turn on a virtual
server for an hour and try out what you're trying to do or for a few hours and use it for as long as you need to
and then when you're done you can turn it off so if you're if your experiment failed you're not that much poorer than
you are at the beginning because you didn't have to you know order all this infrastructure and spend all this time setting it up just keep this in mind as
I talked about open data because this this approach of the cloud and allowing

are provided you know any of us with smartphones and who use services like Airbnb or Netflix and things like that

efficiently with very little risk now I also like to ask answer the
question why does it'll be us even have an open data program why does it matter to us the short answer is because it
matters to our customers we have a lot of customers that operate both on the supply side and the demand side of open
data we have public sector customers whether they're meteorological agencies
like I mentioned before or universities that they're producing massive volume of data and they're spending a lot of
money to produce these volumes of data explicitly for the purpose of sharing them with other researchers their whole
reason to exist and their whole reason to produce these datasets is to get them into the hands of as many people as
possible to drive research and to drive innovation then on the other side of the
coin we have we have customers who are building consumer applications or business-to-business applications or
they might be doing their own research and they depend on access to government data without access to government data
they simply can't do their jobs and we serve both of these customers both of
these sets of customers now when I'm when I talk about open data in this
context I want to be clear that I use a quite broad definition of open data some people believe there's a definition
of open data which is that open data is only data that is publicly available without a without any fees associated
with acquiring it or accessing it with no license restrictions other than
asking for attribution in return we we use a much broader definition of open
data which is that it's data that is made as open as possible by whoever's providing it the
conversation around open data and and the importance of sharing data publicly is a broad conversation and we want to
include as many people as it as we in it as we can we don't want to exclude
people who are who want to share data as openly as possible but can't because it
